Comment: I think I initiated this challenge against a higher-rated player with a higher score in D1. I adopted a suitably conservative opening move.

An interesting move order.  I have vague memories of having been stuffed by White after playing this after 3. cxd5 Nxd5 but I can't believe it's actually wrong.  As White, I continue to take a conservative approach.

White prefers to keep the 2 bishops, if possible.  He needn't worry about Black's KN exposing an attack on the Bh4 because Black can't take any White pieces in the process of revealing the attack and White can merely swap on e7.
Black prepares to fianchetto his q-side B.  His pawn structure already restricts this B.  White's Bishops are much better because of their greater freedom of movement and influence on the position.

With castling, White's development is nearly complete (Rc1 and Qc2 will complete his development), whereas Black still needs to make at least four moves to complete his development (...Bb7, ...0-0, ....Rc8 and ... Qc7 for example)
White engages Black in tactical exchanges before he has completed his development.

I also prefer not to allow my B to be swapped off and instead attack Black's Rc8
I also prefer not to allow my B to be swapped off and instead attack Black's Rc8

Removing one of Black's defenders of his IQP at the expense of giving up my beloved Bishop pair.  They say that chess is often about choosing the right moment to convert one sort of advantage into another and I think I just about got this right, though Black's Bishops do now look strong.

and adding pressure to the isolani by occupying the half-open d-file and preparing to blockade on d4 with the Nf3
and adding pressure to the isolani by occupying the half-open d-file and preparing to blockade on d4 with the Nf3
removing the Q from the same file as White's R and apparently ceding the d-pawn, until White notices that his Nc3 is pinned against his Q

...releasing the pin and increasing the pressure on d5.  There are now 3 attackers on d5 but only one defender.  On the other hand, White still can't use both Nc3 and Rd1 to take on d5, as the Rc1 would be vulnerable...
removing one of the attackers
Now the R on the c-file is properly defended by a pawn but the d-pawn is only attacked by major pieces while it's still defended by a minor piece, so still OK
